intro: Acacia mimica var. angusta, commonly known as the narrow-leaf acacia, is a shrub native to Australia. It features slender, angular stems and narrow, feather-like leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces yellow globular flowers that bloom in late winter to early spring. It is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, making it drought-tolerant. This variety is valued for its ornamental appeal and ability to thrive in well-drained soils.

Its family is Fabaceae, commonly known as the legume or bean family, characterized by pod fruits and often nitrogen-fixing abilities. Its genus is Acacia, a large genus of shrubs and trees known for their distinctive phyllodes and often used in traditional medicine and as timber. Its species is Acacia mimica, a specific type of acacia known for its narrow leaves and is a variant of the species with the botanical name var. angusta.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia mimica var. angusta is primarily native to Western Australia. This variant of Acacia mimica is found in the southern regions of the state, particularly in the areas of the Geraldton and Esperance regions. It typically grows in sandy soils and is often associated with coastal and inland dune environments. The plant is well adapted to the arid and semi-arid conditions of its native habitat. It plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soils and providing habitat for local wildlife.
